To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 15,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Amelita hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving her family a good future through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy grocery items and other products for her store

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna is 32 years old and has two children. They live happily in a rural community where they can plant and harvest rice and vegetables for sale. 

While doing the household chores, Myrna finds time to manage her variety store. She has been operating the business for almost five years and usually earns a profit of PHP 10,000 a month, which she uses for daily consumption and allowances of her children in school. 

She aimed to increase her product offerings to satisfy her customers' demand. But because of insufficient capital, she is asking for a loan of PHP 30,000 to buy additional stocks of soft drinks, biscuits, junk foods, candies, noodles, eggs, meat, and vegetables for sale. 

She believes that this loan will help a lot to improve the business and she hopes she will be successful in the future.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, biscuits, junk foods, candies, noodles, eggs, meat, and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Ma.luisa

texts.en: Ma.Luisa believes that" Success is the fruit of Sacrifices". She is 44 years old, married and has four school-age children. She and her husband agreed to continue sending their children to school so that they will earn a degree and become professionals someday.  Despite the hardships of living, they have the determination to survive as they continue to work hard and strive harder. To generate income, they put up a bakeshop  in their community and they help each other in managing it. They planned to improve the business and prepare more recipes to sell but due to inadequate capital, she is asking for an additional of P50,000 to buy flour, sugar, oils, milk, plastics and trays needed in preparing and making the recipes. She believes that their business will grow and becomes profitable as they continue to manage and make improvements for it.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, oils, milk, plastics and trays needed in the bakery

loans.name: Tuy

texts.en:
Tuy lives in a small thatched house with her spouse and two single children from Baray district, Kompong Tom province. She is now 53 years old and is in the business of farming rice where she can yield a suitable profit. However, it is barely enough to cover her daily expenses due to the high cost of commodities. Tuy’s husband is the main income provider of the family. He works in the construction field, providing construction service to people around and across the province.

Tuy would like to improve her family business and make it more viable for the family. But due to inadequate capital, Tuy decided to take out a loan in the sums of 600,000 KHR to purchase chemical fertilizers to put in her soil and pay for labor costs incurred in transplanting rice. This loan will make her business become more profitable, and she hopes to obtain a good harvest in this coming season.

loans.use: to purchase chemical fertilizers to put in her soil and pay for labor costs incurred in transplanting rice.

loans.name: Marivic

texts.en: Despite the hardship of living, Marivic and her husband aimed to improve their status of living to educate their children and give them a bright future. She is 42 years old and has four school-age children. She is engaged in the hog-raising business to supplement her husband's income. Due to the high cost of commodities and school fees, they need to increase their income to cover their necessities and support the education of their children. To increase her income, Marivic planned to raise more pigs to sell but due to insufficient capital, she is asking for an additional of P40,000 to buy feeds, vitamins and additional piglets to raise. She mentioned that this loan will help her to improve the business and hopes that she will make the business grow and become a viable source of income in the future.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins and additional piglets to raise

loans.name: Kossi

texts.fr: Jeune homme de 36ans, Mr Kossi est marié à une revendeuse et ils ont 03 enfants dont 02 scolarisés. L’ainé a 10ans et le dernier 03ans. Pour bien répondre aux besoins de la famille il s’est lancé dans la vente des produits de beauté dans une boutique. Pour renforcer son stock de marchandises il sollicite l’aide de WAGES par ce troisième prêt pour acheter des marchandises (déodorant, parfums et savons). Avec les profits, il prévoit avoir une grande boutique pour vendre en gros, avoir d’autres boutiques dans les coins de la ville de Lomé et envoyer ses enfants pour les études en Europe.
texts.en:
Kossi is 36 years old, and he is married to a reseller with whom he has three children.  Two of his children go to school.  His oldest child is 10, the youngest is 3.

In order to adequately meet his family's needs, Kossi has started to sell cosmetic products in a shop.

In order to boost his inventory, he is requesting assistance from WAGES and is taking a third loan, which will be used to buy such goods as deodorants, perfumes and soaps.

With his profits, Kossi is planning to have a larger wholesale shop, to open other shops in various neighborhoods of Lomé, and to send his children to Europe, for their studies.

loans.use: to buy cosmetic products.

loans.name: Al-Suadh Group

texts.en: This group is called Al-Suadh and consists of four ladies who live in Taiz, Yemen. Afrah is 39 years old. She is a housewife and has a house. She applied for a loan of 50,000 Yemeni rials from Al-Amal Microfinance Bank to buy construction supplies like cement, etc., for her house.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies like cement, etc., for her house

loans.name: Mt Usambara Group

texts.en:
Daudi, who is in his early 50s, is married with six children, three of whom are adults and three of whom still go to school. He has been running a food shop for about two years now. He works from 6 am to 9 pm daily and he is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be his second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. He used the previous loan to buy more stock of sugar, rice and different kind of soaps and he has paid back his loan successfully. He hopes for a new loan to buy iron sheets to build a food shop room. His dream is to build a new good house, buy a farm and start a new chicken business.

He will share this loan with his loan group "Mt Usambara", which consists of 10 members who will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy iron sheets to build a room for his food store

loans.name: Chhit

texts.en:
Chhit is 44 years old and married to a humble villager who works in the same type of business, farming, as her. They don’t have any children but they wish one very soon. Chhit cultivates and harvests rice, vegetables, and other seasonal crops according to each season. She has been in this business for the past 10 years and earns a decent income to cover her daily costs.

Chhit is requesting a loan for 700,000 KHR, which she will use to hire laborers to transplant the rice and to purchase sacks of fertilizers for her crop care. She wants to expand her business in the future and hopes to upgrade her standard of living.

loans.use: to hire laborers to transplant the rice and to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Dominga

texts.en:
This is Dominga.   She previously received a 19,000 PHP loan that she used to pay for raw materials and supplies needed in salted-egg production. Her earnings were a big help in meeting her personal, household, and business expenditures. 

She would like to apply for another 50,000 PHP loan to buy eggs, trays, and other materials and ingredients needed in making salted eggs. Her profits from business will definitely help her to sustain her daily, personal and business needs. 

She looks forward to this financial increase with gladness and thankfulness in her heart. 

Dominga dreams of expanding her business, and she hopes to support her family through her hard work.. She also aspires to draw more customers in the future. Every week she faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of their work and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.
 
* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy raw materials and supplies needed in producing salted eggs.

loans.name: Kang

texts.en: Kang, 38, is in a direct-selling business. She collects fish from local farmers in her community and resells them in a small market.  She has been in this type of business for almost 5 years, earning in the neighborhood of 8,000 KHR per day.  Kang’s challenge in the business is that she sometimes cannot sell all her fish during the day, and those fish become rotten. Kang wants to overcome this challenge and increase her selling productivity by going through her commune selling her fish house to house. This will enable her to prevent a large loss. But Kang needs a vehicle to work out this plan. As a result, she is asking for a loan from HKL and Kiva to purchase a motorcycle, which will be used to transport her fish to sell door to door. Someday, with good profits from the business, she will provide a higher education to her three children.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle, which will be used to transport her fish for selling.

loans.name: Wega Group

texts.en:
Nelly, who is in her early 20's, is married.  She has been a food vendor for about three years now. She works from 5am to 11pm daily and she is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to add food stock and buy a fridge, and she paid household expenses and has paid back all her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to start a grocery business (buying water, sodas and beers). Her dream is to one day be able to own a big grocery.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Wega" which has 13 members.The members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan.

loans.use: to buy water, sodas and beer.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
This is Marilyn, 40, resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Junie, a driver, and a mother to her children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Marilyn operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 pesos worth of cooking oil or an egg. She earns a profit by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 30,000 PHP loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marilyn hopes to grow her business and dreams of giving a good and quality education to her children through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Pheach

texts.en:
Pheach is a resident living from Reussey Keo district, a suburb of Phnom Penh. He is now 45 years old and married to his wife, who helps him generate income for their family with her grocery store. Together, they have six children.  Three of them are employed in a garment factory to help their parents financially; the younger three attend school and are still in need of daily allowances. Pheach is a professional teacher at a state school, and he can earn a decent salary from the government.

With the loan of 1,500 USD, Pheach would like to purchase more stocks of merchandise for his wife's store, such as shampoos, powders, snacks, sweets, spices, canned items, noodle, beverages, personal beauty products, home use products, and other household items. Through this purchase, they hope that they will be able to satisfy more customers and thereby raise more income.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of merchandise for his wife's store.
